conversation.content: So, um, did you manage to find, you know, a menorah that wasn't kind of sold out everywhere?
Well, I ended up ordering one from West Elm online, basically, their brass one with the modern design, but err, shipping took forever since everyone's buying them right now.
Oh wow, so, are you still doing that, I mean, big party you were planning, actually, for the eighth night?
Honestly, yes! I've got latkes from Goldbelly coming in frozen, uhh, those fancy ones from Russ & Daughters, and I sort of splurged on some artisanal sufganiyot from this Brooklyn bakery.
Did you really [laugh hysterically] order frozen latkes instead of making them from scratch like bubbe would?
Look, hmm, between work and everything else, the thing is, I'd rather spend time with family than, like, standing over hot oil for three hours straight.
Mom's going to be [bitter] so disappointed when she finds out you're outsourcing tradition.
She'll get over it when she tastes them - plus I got her favorite chocolate coins from Vosges, the ones with sea salt and exotic spices she loves.
Uh, speaking of gifts, anyway, [sneeze] did you remember to, I guess, get something for all eight nights?
Actually, [sad] I'm struggling with that because, you know, I wanted to support small businesses but umm, everything from Etsy and Uncommon Goods is backordered until January.
Wait, er, you're telling me you didn't plan ahead, really, even though Hanukkah is, okay so, the same time every year?
Basically, I had everything in my cart from The Grommet, ah, these beautiful handmade dreidels and mezuzah cases, but just procrastinated on actually checking out.
That's [sniffle] exactly what happened to me with the kids' presents.
Have you tried Maisonette for the kids? They have this whole Hanukkah collection with educational toys and books that actually ship same-day in some cities.
I, sort of, forgot they existed, well, but honestly, aren't they super expensive?
They're definitely pricey, but their curation is incredible - plus they have this partnership with PJ Library for Jewish children's books that are actually engaging.
Do you think, like, the kids even care where their presents, um, come from anyway?
Probably not, but I care about supporting brands that actually understand our traditions instead of just slapping blue and white on generic holiday stuff.
Fair point - remember last year's "Hanukkah bush" fiasco at Target?
Oh god yes, that was so cringeworthy, but [very quietly] at least Crate & Barrel and CB2 have gotten better at offering authentic Judaica alongside their regular holiday collections.
